abstract.para:
In this unit you will learn how to
Say 'hello' and 'goodbye'
Exchange greetings
Observe basic courtesies
Ask people to speak more slowly

section.title: Before you start
section.para: Read the Introduction to the course. This gives some useful advice on studying alone and how to make the most of the course.

Make sure you've got your recording next to you as you'll need it to listen to the Pronunciation guide and Dialogues sections. If you don't have the recording, use the Pronunciation guide in the book.

row.entry: I am well - how about you?

note.para: When you see a linking mark '_' between two words, sound the last letter of the first word as though it were attached to the next word: vous parlez_anglais?

section.title: Dialogues
section.para: Listen to the recording and hear people practicing saying 'hello' and greeting each other in French.
Press the pause button after each sentence and repeat aloud.

note.para: Pay particular attention to the way the 's' in Messieurs and Monsieur is pronounced. It should sound as in pass and not as in shop.

section.title: SIMPLE QUESTIONS
section.para: The simplest way of asking something in French is to raise your voice on the last syllable (part of a word):
Now practise saying pardon? (to have something repeated) and pardon (to apologize or attract someone's attention).

section.title: REFUSING POLITELY IN FRENCH
section.para: If you want to refuse something in France, you can say non merci or merci on its own.

section.title: CALLING THE WAITER'S ATTENTION
section.para: Although garcon is the word for waiter, today you would usually say Monsieur to attract his attention. For a waitress, you say Madame or Mademoiselle as you think fir or just look expectant and say s'il vous plait.

note.para: Don't forget to shorten Mademoiselle to Mad'moiselle to make it sound more French!

section.title: HOW TO BE COURTEOUS
section.para: In France when you're talking to someone you don't know very well, it's polite to add Monsieur, Madame, Mademoiselle particularly after short phrases like oui, non, bonjour or merci.
The French shake hands with good friends and acquaintances every time they meet or say goodbye. Kissing (on both cheeks) is reserved for family and close friends.

section.title: WHEN TO USE TU (YOU) AND WHEN TO USE VOUS (YOU)
section.para: The equivalent of you in French can be either tu or vous. French people use tu when speaking to children, teenagers, relations and close friends. They use vous in work and business situations or when speaking to senior or old people: vous is also used to address a group of people to whom one might say tu individually. The best advice is to say vous until you are addressed as tu or asked to use the tu form: on se tutoie? shall we call each other tu?
